node.contents: Do you actually need to customize serialization with `writeObject()`/`readObject()`?

astNode.text: Do you actually need to customize serialization with `writeObject()`/`readObject()`?

node.contents: I'm using a simple struct where I store readonly values (like properties with no setter in C#). To achieve this I'm using public final int test=42;.

astNode.text: I'm using a simple struct where I store readonly values (like properties with no setter in C#). To achieve this I'm using public final int test=42;.

node.contents: For some reasons I want to allow to serialize this class. I'm using this code:

astNode.text: For some reasons I want to allow to serialize this class. I'm using this code:

elements.contents: private void writeObject(ObjectOutputStream oos) throws IOException { oos.writeInt(test); } private void readObject(ObjectInputStream ois) throws IOException { test=ois.readInt(); }

units.rawText: private void writeObject(ObjectOutputStream oos) throws IOException { oos.writeInt(test); } private void readObject(ObjectInputStream ois) throws IOException { test=ois.readInt(); }

node.contents: The last one does not work because the field test is final how can I solve this issue?

astNode.text: The last one does not work because the field test is final how can I solve this issue?

node.contents: firstly, a public final primitive constant can be made public static final and doesn't need to be serialised because its always the same value.

astNode.text: firstly, a public final primitive constant can be made public static final and doesn't need to be serialised because its always the same value.

node.contents: However, say you have a field which is set by a constructor can can be different.

astNode.text: However, say you have a field which is set by a constructor can can be different.

elements.contents: int test=ois.readInt(); Field testField = getClass().getDeclaredField("test"); testField.setAccessible(true); testField.set(this, test);

units.rawText: int test=ois.readInt(); Field testField = getClass().getDeclaredField("test"); testFieldsetAccessible(true); testFieldset(this, test);

node.contents: Note: security managers often doesn't allow this if you have one.

astNode.text: Note: security managers often doesn't allow this if you have one.

node.contents: You can use reflection to modify the value of test

astNode.text: You can use reflection to modify the value of test

elements.contents: // Get the Class object for the class of which test is a field Class<?> myClass = MyClass.class; // We will need to set test as accessible so as to change it's value // Get the Field object for test Field testField = myClass.getDeclaredField("test"); // Save the current accessibility of test boolean wasAccessible = testField.isAccessible(); // Mark test as accessible testField.setAccessible(true); // Set the value of test for this instance of MyClass int newTestValue = 42; testField.setInt(this, newTestValue); // Restore the accesibility of test to it's original testField.setAccessible(wasAccessible);

fragments.text: // Get the Class object for the

comments.text: // We will need to set test as accessible so as to change it's value // Get the Field object for test Field testField = myClass.getDeclaredField("test"); // Save the current accessibility of test boolean wasAccessible = testField.isAccessible(); // Mark test as accessible testField.setAccessible(true); // Set the value of test for this instance of MyClass int newTestValue = 42; testField.setInt(this, newTestValue); // Restore the accesibility of test to it's original testField.setAccessible(wasAccessible);

units.rawText: // Get the Class object for the class of which test is a field Class<?> myClass = MyClass.class; // We will need to set test as accessible so as to change it's value // Get the Field object for test Field testField = myClass.getDeclaredField("test"); // Save the current accessibility of test boolean wasAccessible = testField.isAccessible(); // Mark test as accessible testField.setAccessible(true); // Set the value of test for this instance of MyClass int newTestValue = 42; testField.setInt(this, newTestValue); // Restore the accesibility of test to it's original testField.setAccessible(wasAccessible);

node.contents: The above assumes that your application has the permissions given by the SecurityManager to use reflection. If it does not, the SecurityManager will throw an exception.

astNode.text: The above assumes that your application has the permissions given by the SecurityManager to use reflection. If it does not, the SecurityManager will throw an exception.

node.contents: This is the right way to manage final fields and serialization. Using reflection is overkill and susceptible to not working in some setups.

astNode.text: This is the right way to manage final fields and serialization. Using reflection is overkill and susceptible to not working in some setups.

node.contents: This is certainly the better idea, but do note that `defaultReadObject` and `defaultWriteObject` use reflection under the hood as well (including a lot of caching and things you probably couldn't be bothered with).

astNode.text: This is certainly the better idea, but do note that `defaultReadObject` and `defaultWriteObject` use reflection under the hood as well (including a lot of caching and things you probably couldn't be bothered with).

node.contents: readObject should always start with defaultReadObject or readFields; writeObject with defaultWriteObject or putFields. defaultReadObject will set the final field for you.

astNode.text: readObject should always start with defaultReadObject or readFields; writeObject with defaultWriteObject or putFields. defaultReadObject will set the final field for you.

node.contents: If you want to use readFields, then either remove the final, or stash in a temporary field and implement readResolve (note the original object will still be available to interested parties). Generally you really don't want to resort to the likes of sun.misc.Unsafe.

astNode.text: If you want to use readFields, then either remove the final, or stash in a temporary field and implement readResolve (note the original object will still be available to interested parties). Generally you really don't want to resort to the likes of sun.misc.Unsafe.

node.contents: (The new Java Memory Model (JMM) introduce in J2SE 5.0 (and implemented in JDK 1.4) gives more liberties in the way final field can be optimised. In the example code of the question, the field is initialised with a compile-time constant expression. As such I'd expect it to be inlined (not tested).)

astNode.text: (The new Java Memory Model (JMM) introduce in J2SE 5.0 (and implemented in JDK 1.4) gives more liberties in the way final field can be optimised. In the example code of the question, the field is initialised with a compile-time constant expression. As such I'd expect it to be inlined (not tested).)

node.contents: Does the value of this final field change for each object or is it the same for all objects? i.e. is it set at the constructor or the field declaration level? If it stays the same, the simplest solution here would be to make it static and do away with the extra overhead of reading and writing the "read-only" values. Also, is it mandatory for you to provide the readObject and writeObject implementations rather than relying on the default mechanism?

astNode.text: Does the value of this final field change for each object or is it the same for all objects? i.e. is it set at the constructor or the field declaration level? If it stays the same, the simplest solution here would be to make it static and do away with the extra overhead of reading and writing the "read-only" values. Also, is it mandatory for you to provide the readObject and writeObject implementations rather than relying on the default mechanism?
